Professing athletes and social activism don't always go hand in hand, but don't tell that to NBA star Ira Newble.
The Cleveland Cavalier was outraged after he read an article in USA Today about the crisis in Darfur, Sudan.
Newble didn't just put down the paper, he decided to do something to help.
He and a colleague drafted a letter addressed to the Chinese government.
The letter criticized its ties to the Sudanese government.
China is hosting the 2008 Summer Olympics and Newble plans to send the letter to the president of the International Olympic Committee as well.
But the big problem isn't getting the letter to China, it's getting fellow NBA players and other professional athletes to sign on.
Ira Newble told NPR's Tony Cox, why he decided to speak out about Darfur and how many signatures he's collected so far.
Right now I have - I believe 17 or 18 signatures, thus far - mostly my team, 13 of my teammates.
I have five.
I was very successful, actually, with my team.
Everybody signed with the exception to LeBron and Damon - Damon Jones.
My teammates supporting me instantly.
I brought them together, passed out a packet of information and explained to them in detail what was really going on and what I was trying to do.
And most them, they signed the letter instantly.
When are you going to present the letter to the Chinese government?
I haven't picked a date yet.
I still have some time(unintelligible) out of Olympic stadium next summer.
So I'm not sure.
I'm trying to get as many people onboard and many signatures as possible before I do present it.
A number of people have written over the years about athletes, particularly black athletes, when it comes to their political activism or their lack of political activism.
Since you've undertaken this project, what have you learned about what it takes to be an athlete and to be politically active at the same time?
Well, first, it is time consuming.
And you have to be dedicated to do it.
You might jeopardize your job or you might jeopardize marketing deals issues that you come across.
And you know, that's just something I'm willing to do.
You know, a lot of people don't like athletes speaking out on certain issues.

But times right now - the problem, I believe, is a lot of athletes aren't informed and aren't aware of worldly issues, and not just athletes but young people, overall, are not aware of what's going on.

And where, I believe, in one study, a few months back, how many African-Americans actually know what's going on in the world or watch the news outside the world, and it was less than like 30-35 percent.
And we have to do better than that.
You know, we need to know what's going on.
And guys - young guys need to get involved and help more than they can because we have a voice.
You know, a lot of kids definitely look up to us.
So, we need to use that and use that as a springboard to help other people.
Are you politically active generally or have you always been?
Not active but conscious.
I could say that I've been politically and socially conscious, but I'm not more of an activist, but just I started it right here, so I'm active now.
And I'm hoping that I could continue to help.
And by me being in the NBA, I have a voice, and I believe that I could help a lot of people.
What is it exactly, Ira, that you want to do?
What do you want to happen?
Well, ultimately, I want to stop the killing.
You know, too many people have been murdered and thousands of women have been raped in Sudan.
And two and a half million people have been displaced from their homes.
And people need to be awake and open up their eyes and be aware of what's going on in the world.
A lot of people that I have contacted about this didn't even really know how severe it was and don't know what's going on over there.
So I wanted, first of all, make people aware of what's going on, and then, get some help in there.
And, you know, the NBA is a global market.
It's a large global market and they have a large fan base in China.
So, I felt like a letter first from NBA players expressing their concern about, you know, their investments in Darfur will help.
What did the NBA say about this?
The NBA, at first, didn't really know - they didn't - they haven't been negative.
I can't say they've been extremely happy.
I do believe the NBA has financial ties to China.
But they haven't been negative, you know.
They definitely support, you know, they have supported me and I haven't had any negative feedback so far.
But you sound, Ira, like this is tricky area, this is a very delicate area to be maneuvering in not only with the government of China but with your own employers, the NBA.
As a veteran, it's amazing.
